pli-tv-kd10:1.8.1: The Buddha got up from his seat, went to those monks who were siding with the ejected monk, and sat down on a prepared seat. He then said to those monks:
pli-tv-kd10:1.8.2: “If you have committed an offense, don’t refuse to make amends for it just because you think that you haven’t committed it.
pli-tv-kd10:1.8.3: It may be that a monk has committed an offense.
pli-tv-kd10:1.8.4: He doesn’t regard it as an offense, but there are other monks who do.
pli-tv-kd10:1.8.5: If that monk knows, ‘These monks are learned and masters of the tradition; they are experts on the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the summaries; they are knowledgeable and competent, have a sense of conscience, and are afraid of wrongdoing and fond of the training. They are unlikely, because of me or anyone else, to act wrongly out of desire, ill will, confusion, or fear.
pli-tv-kd10:1.8.6: Moreover, if these monks eject me for not recognizing an offense, they won’t do the observance-day procedure with me. pli-tv-kd10:1.9.1: Soon those monks who sided with the ejected monk did the observance-day procedure and the legal procedures of the Sangha right there within the monastic boundary.
pli-tv-kd10:1.9.2: But the monks who had ejected him went outside the boundary and did the observance-day procedure and the procedures of the Sangha there.
pli-tv-kd10:1.9.3: One of the monks who had done the ejecting went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd10:1.9.4: and told him what was happening.
pli-tv-kd10:1.9.7: The Buddha replied: “If those monks who side with the ejected monk do the observance-day procedure and the legal procedures of the Sangha right there within the monastic boundary, and it’s in accordance with the motion and announcements as I have laid them down, then those procedures are legitimate, irreversible, and fit to stand.
pli-tv-kd10:1.9.8: And if you, the monks who did the ejecting, do the observance-day procedure and the legal procedures of the Sangha right there within the monastic boundary, and it’s in accordance with the motion and announcements as I have laid them down, then those procedures too are legitimate, irreversible, and fit to stand.
pli-tv-kd10:1.10.1: This is so because you belong to different Buddhist sect.
pli-tv-kd10:1.10.2: There are these two grounds for belonging to a different Buddhist sect.
pli-tv-kd10:1.10.3: Either one makes oneself belong to a different Buddhist sect, or a unanimous assembly ejects one for not recognizing an offense, for not making amends for an offense, or for not giving up a bad view.
pli-tv-kd10:1.10.5: And there are these two grounds for belonging to the same Buddhist sect.
pli-tv-kd10:1.10.6: Either one makes oneself belong to the same Buddhist sect, or a unanimous assembly re-admits one who had been ejected for not recognizing an offense, for not making amends for an offense, or for not giving up a bad view.”
pli-tv-kd10:2.1.1: At this time the monks were arguing and disputing in the dining halls in inhabited areas, displaying improper physical and verbal behavior, such as grabbing one another with their hands.

pli-tv-kd10:2.1.11: and after criticizing them he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd10:2.3.2: “At one time in Benares, monks, there was a king of Kāsī called Brahmadatta. He was rich and powerful, had many vehicles and transport animals, and possessed a large kingdom and much wealth.
pli-tv-kd10:2.3.3: Then there was Dīghīti, the King of Kosala, who was poor and had little power, who had few vehicles and transport animals, and who possessed only a small kingdom and little wealth.
pli-tv-kd10:2.3.4: At one time King Brahmadatta, armed with his fourfold army, marched out to attack King Dīghīti.
pli-tv-kd10:2.3.5: When King Dīghīti heard about this,
pli-tv-kd10:2.3.6: he reflected on King Brahmadatta’s superior wealth and power and concluded, ‘I’m incapable of repelling even a single strike from Brahmadatta.
pli-tv-kd10:2.3.7: Let me flee the town before he arrives.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.3.8: And he fled the town together with his queen.
pli-tv-kd10:2.3.9: King Brahmadatta then conquered and seized the army, the vehicles and transport animals, and the country and wealth of King Dīghīti.
pli-tv-kd10:2.3.10: King Dīghīti and his wife set out for Benares.
pli-tv-kd10:2.3.11: When they eventually arrived, they stayed in the house of a potter on the edge of the town, disguised as wanderers.
pli-tv-kd10:2.4.2: She craved to see the fully armed fourfold army standing on even ground at sunrise and to drink water from the washing of swords.
pli-tv-kd10:2.4.4: and he replied, ‘How are we going to achieve that when we’re in such a difficult situation?’
pli-tv-kd10:2.4.5: ‘If I don’t get it, I’ll die.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.5.1: At that time King Brahmadatta had a brahmin counselor who was a friend of King Dīghīti.
pli-tv-kd10:2.5.2: King Dīghīti went to his friend and told him about his wife’s pregnancy
pli-tv-kd10:2.5.4: The brahmin replied, ‘Well then, let me see the queen.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.5.5: The queen then went to that brahmin.
pli-tv-kd10:2.5.6: When he saw her coming, he got up from his seat, put his upper robe over one shoulder, raise his joined palms, and exclaimed an inspired utterance three times:
pli-tv-kd10:2.5.7: ‘You have the King of Kosala in your womb!’
pli-tv-kd10:2.5.9: You’ll get to see the fully armed fourfold army standing on even ground at sunrise and to drink water from the washing of swords.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.6.1: The brahmin counselor then went to King Brahmadatta and said,
pli-tv-kd10:2.6.2: ‘The omens are such, Sir, that tomorrow you should have the fully armed fourfold army stand on even ground at sunrise and have the swords washed.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.6.3: The king told his people to act accordingly.
pli-tv-kd10:2.6.4: And as a consequence the queen was able to satisfy her craving.
pli-tv-kd10:2.6.5: When the pregnancy matured, the queen gave birth to a son.
pli-tv-kd10:2.6.7: Soon enough Prince Dīghāvu became self-reliant.
pli-tv-kd10:2.7.1: King Dīghīti thought, ‘This King Brahmadatta has caused us much misfortune; he has taken our army, our vehicles and transport animals, and our country and wealth. If he finds out about us, he will kill all three of us. Let me take Prince Dīghāvu to live out-of-town.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.7.3: As he was living outside of town, Prince Dīghāvu was soon training in all branches of knowledge.
pli-tv-kd10:2.8.1: At this time King Dīghīti’s old barber was living under King Brahmadatta.
pli-tv-kd10:2.8.2: On one occasion he saw King Dīghīti and his wife staying in that potter’s house, disguised as wanderers. He then went to King Brahmadatta and told him.

pli-tv-kd10:2.10.2: When he entered Benares, he saw what was happening to his parents.

pli-tv-kd10:2.11.3: And who is he saying this to?’
pli-tv-kd10:2.11.6: ‘I’m not insane; I’m not babbling. Those who are wise will understand.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.11.7: King Dīghīti repeated what he had said to the Prince a second

pli-tv-kd10:2.11.20: Then, when the parading was finished, the people took King Dīghīti and his wife through the southern gate and cut them into four pieces. They placed the pieces at the four directions, set up guard, and departed.
pli-tv-kd10:2.12.1: Prince Dīghāvu entered Benares, brought back some alcohol, and gave it to the guards.
pli-tv-kd10:2.12.2: When they were lying drunken on the ground, he collected sticks, made a funeral pile, and placed his parents’ bodies on top. He then lit the pile, and with joined palms raised, he circumambulated it with his right side toward it.
pli-tv-kd10:2.12.3: Just then King Brahmadatta was up in his best stilt house
pli-tv-kd10:2.12.4: and he saw Prince Dīghāvu circumambulating the funeral pile with joined palms raised. He thought,
pli-tv-kd10:2.12.5: ‘No doubt this is a relative of King Dīghīti. This is surely a sign of trouble for me, in as much as nobody has told me.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.13.1: The Prince then went into the wilderness and cried his heart out. Wiping away his tears, he entered Benares and went to the elephant stables next to the royal compound. He said to the elephant trainer,
pli-tv-kd10:2.13.2: ‘Teacher, I wish to learn the profession.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.13.4: Soon the Prince got up early in the morning. He sang sweetly and played the lute in the elephant stables.
pli-tv-kd10:2.13.5: King Brahmadatta, too, got up early in the morning, and he heard Prince Dīghāvu singing. He asked his people
pli-tv-kd10:2.14.2: and they replied, ‘Sir, it’s a young brahmin who is an apprentice of such-and-such an elephant trainer.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.14.5: and the King asked him whether he was the one who had been singing and playing the lute.
pli-tv-kd10:2.14.6: When the Prince confirmed that it was he,
pli-tv-kd10:2.14.7: the King said, ‘Well then, sing and play right here.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.14.8: Dīghāvu consented and did his best to please the King.
pli-tv-kd10:2.14.9: The King said, ‘Young brahmin, please attend on me,’
pli-tv-kd10:2.14.11: The Prince then got up before King and went to bed after him. He willingly performed any services and was pleasant in his conduct and speech.
pli-tv-kd10:2.14.12: Soon the King put the Prince in an intimate position of trust.
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.1: On one occasion the King said to the Prince,
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.2: ‘Please harness a chariot and let’s go hunting.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.3: He did as asked and said to the King,
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.4: ‘Sir, the chariot is harnessed. Please go at your convenience.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.5: The King then mounted the chariot
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.7: But he drove it away from the army.
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.8: When they had gone a long way, the King said to the Prince,
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.9: ‘Unharness the chariot. I’m tired and I want to lie down.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.10: He did as asked and then sat down cross-legged on the ground.
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.11: The King lay down, resting his head on the Prince’s lap.
pli-tv-kd10:2.15.12: And because he was tired, he quickly fell asleep.

pli-tv-kd10:2.16.27: and each time he ended up returning the sword to its sheath.
pli-tv-kd10:2.16.28: Then King Brahmadatta suddenly got up, frightened and alarmed.
pli-tv-kd10:2.16.29: The Prince asked what was the matter,
pli-tv-kd10:2.16.30: and the King said, ‘Just now, I dreamed that Prince Dīghāvu, the son of Dīghīti the King of Kosala, attacked me with a sword.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.1: Seizing the King’s head with his left hand and drawing his sword with his right hand, the Prince said to the King,
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.2: ‘Sir, I’m that Prince Dīghāvu, the son of Dīghīti the King of Kosala.
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.3: You have caused us much misfortune.
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.4: You took our army, our vehicles and transport animals, and our country and wealth.
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.5: You killed my mother and father.
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.6: This is a good opportunity for me to take revenge.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.7: The King bowed down with his head at the Prince’s feet and said,
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.9: ‘Who am I to spare your life?
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.10: Sir, it’s you who should spare mine.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.11: ‘Well then, Dīghāvu, if you spare my life, I’ll spare yours.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.12: And the King and Dīghāvu spared each other’s lives. They shook hands and made a vow not to harm each other.
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.13: The King said to the Prince,
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.14: ‘Well then, Dīghāvu, harness the chariot and let’s go.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.15: He did as asked and said to the King,
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.16: ‘The chariot is harnessed. Please go at your own convenience.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.17.19: And he drove it so that it soon rejoined the army.
pli-tv-kd10:2.18.1: When he was back in Benares, the King gathered his court and said,
pli-tv-kd10:2.18.2: ‘If you saw Prince Dīghāvu, the son of Dīghīti the King of Kosala, what would you do to him?’
pli-tv-kd10:2.18.4: ‘Sir, we would cut off his hands;’
pli-tv-kd10:2.18.6: ‘we would cut off his hands and feet;’
pli-tv-kd10:2.18.9: ‘we would cut off his ears and nose;’
pli-tv-kd10:2.18.11: ‘This is Prince Dīghāvu, the son of Dīghīti the King of Kosala.
pli-tv-kd10:2.18.12: You shouldn’t do anything to harm him.
pli-tv-kd10:2.18.13: I’ve spared his life and he has spared mine.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.19.1: Soon afterwards the King said to Dīghāvu,
pli-tv-kd10:2.19.2: ‘Dīghāvu, what’s the meaning of that which your father told you at the time of his death?’
pli-tv-kd10:2.19.5: ‘When he said, “Not long,” he meant, “Don’t harbor hate for a long time.”
pli-tv-kd10:2.19.7: When he said, “Not short,” he meant, “Don’t hastily break with your friends.”
pli-tv-kd10:2.19.9: And when he said, “For hatred never ends through hatred; hatred only ends through love,” he was referring to your killing of my mother and father.
pli-tv-kd10:2.19.10: For if I had killed you, those who wish you well would have killed me, and those who wish me well would in turn have killed them.
pli-tv-kd10:2.19.11: In this way the hatred would never end through hatred.
pli-tv-kd10:2.19.12: But now you have spared my life and I’ve spared yours.
pli-tv-kd10:2.19.13: In this way hatred ends through love.’
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.3: how wise Dīghāvu is, in that he’s able to fully understand the meaning of his father’s brief statement.’ And he gave him back his father’s army, his vehicles and transport animals, and his country and wealth, and he also gave him his own daughter.
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.4: In this way, monks, those kings who had the authority to punish were actually patient and gentle.
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.5: But you who have gone forth on this well-proclaimed spiritual path, you shine when you are patient and gentle.”
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.6: A third time the Buddha said to those monks
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.8: And for third time that monk who spoke contrary to the Teaching replied,
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.9: “Wait, Sir. You are the Lord of the Teaching
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.10: and there is no need for you to be concerned. Just enjoy the happiness of the present life.
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.11: We’ll face the consequences of this quarreling and disputing.”
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.13: “These foolish men are overpowered by emotions. It’s not easy to persuade them,”
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.14: and he got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd10:2.20.15: The first section for recitation on Dīghāvu is finished.
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.1: After robing up in the morning, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and entered Kosambī for alms.
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.2: He walked for alms and had his meal, and after returning from almsround, he put his dwelling in order. He then took his bowl and robe, and while standing in the midst of the Sangha, he spoke these verses:
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.4: No-one thinks they are a fool.
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.6: They do not think it through.
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.10: They don’t know what leads them on.
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.12: They defeated me, they robbed me.’
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.13: For those who carry on like this,
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.16: They defeated me, they robbed me.’
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.17: For those who do not carry on like this,
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.21: Only by love does it stop—
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.28: Those taking cows, horses, and wealth,
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.32: If you get a discerning friend,
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.33: A steadfast companion, good to live with,
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.35: And go with them, glad and mindful.
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.36: If you do not get a discerning friend,
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.37: A steadfast companion, good to live with,
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.38: Then like a king giving up his kingdom,
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.39: Wander alone like a bull elephant in the forest.
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.41: For there is no friendship with fools.
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.42: Wander alone and do no bad,
pli-tv-kd10:3.1.43: Unconcerned, like a bull elephant in the forest.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.0: The account of going to Bālakaloṇaka
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.1: After speaking these verses while standing in the midst of the Sangha, the Buddha went to the village of Bālakaloṇaka.
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.2: At that time Venerable Bhagu was staying near that village.
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.3: When Bhagu saw the Buddha coming, he prepared a seat and set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet. He then went out to meet the Buddha, receiving his bowl and robe.
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.4: The Buddha sat down on the prepared seat and washed his feet.
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.5: When Bhagu had bowed and sat down,
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.7: “I hope you are keeping well, monk,
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.8: I hope you’re comfortable; I hope you’re not having any trouble getting almsfood?”
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.9: “I’m keeping well, Venerable Sir, I’m comfortable;
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.10: I’m having no trouble getting almsfood.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.1.11: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened Bhagu with a teaching. He then got up from his seat and went to the Eastern Bamboo Park.
pli-tv-kd10:4.2.0: The account of going to the Eastern Bamboo Park
pli-tv-kd10:4.2.1: At this time Venerable Anuruddha, Venerable Nandiya, and Venerable Kimila were staying at the Eastern Bamboo Park.
pli-tv-kd10:4.2.2: The park keeper saw the Buddha coming and said to him,
pli-tv-kd10:4.2.4: There are three ascetics from good families staying here, seeking their own benefit.
pli-tv-kd10:4.2.6: When Anuruddha heard the park keeper advising the Buddha, he said,
pli-tv-kd10:4.2.8: It’s our teacher who has arrived.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.2.9: Anuruddha then went to Nandiya and Kimila and said,
pli-tv-kd10:4.2.10: “Come out, Venerables, our teacher has arrived.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.3.1: The three of them went out to meet the Buddha. One received his bowl and robe, one prepared a seat, and one put out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet.
pli-tv-kd10:4.3.2: The Buddha sat down on the prepared seat and washed his feet.
pli-tv-kd10:4.3.3: When they had bowed and sat down,
pli-tv-kd10:4.3.5: “I hope you are all keeping well, Anuruddha, I hope you’re comfortable;
pli-tv-kd10:4.3.6: I hope you’re not having any trouble getting almsfood?”
pli-tv-kd10:4.3.7: “We are keeping well, Venerable Sir, we’re comfortable,
pli-tv-kd10:4.3.8: and we’re not having any trouble getting almsfood.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.3.9: “I hope you’re living together in harmony, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and that you regard one another with affection?”
pli-tv-kd10:4.3.10: “Yes, we are living together in harmony, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and we regard one another with affection.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.4.2: ‘How fortunate I am to be living with such fellow monastics!’
pli-tv-kd10:4.4.3: And I do acts of kindness toward them, by body,
pli-tv-kd10:4.4.5: and mind, both in public and in private.
pli-tv-kd10:4.4.7: ‘Let me set aside what I wish to do and instead do what these venerables wish.’
pli-tv-kd10:4.4.9: We are separate in body, but it’s as if we’re one in mind.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.4.10: Nandiya and Kimila then repeated what Anuruddha had said.
pli-tv-kd10:4.5.1: “I hope, Anuruddha, that you’re heedful and energetic?”
pli-tv-kd10:4.5.3: “And how is it that you’re heedful and energetic?”
pli-tv-kd10:4.5.4: “Whoever returns first from almsround in the village, he prepares the seats and sets out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet. He washes and sets out the bowl for leftovers, and puts out water for drinking and water for washing.
pli-tv-kd10:4.5.5: Whoever returns last from almsround may eat the leftovers, or he discards them where there are no cultivated plants
pli-tv-kd10:4.5.7: He puts away the seats and also the foot-stool, the foot scraper, and the water for washing the feet. He cleans the bowl for leftovers and puts it away, puts away the water for drinking and the water for washing, and sweeps the dining hall.
pli-tv-kd10:4.5.8: Whoever sees that the pot for drinking water, the pot for washing water, or the waterpot in the restroom is empty fills it.
pli-tv-kd10:4.5.9: If he can’t do it by himself, he calls someone over by hand signal and they move it together. We don’t speak because of that.
pli-tv-kd10:4.5.10: And every five days we sit together the whole night and talk about the Teaching.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.6.0: The account of going to Pālileyyaka
pli-tv-kd10:4.6.1: The Buddha then instructed, inspired, and gladdened Venerable Anuruddha, Venerable Nandiya, and Venerable Kimila with a teaching. He then got up from his seat and set out wandering toward Pālileyyaka.
pli-tv-kd10:4.6.3: he stayed in a protected forest grove, at the foot of an auspicious sal tree.
pli-tv-kd10:4.6.4: While he was staying by himself, the Buddha thought,
pli-tv-kd10:4.6.5: “When I was previously surrounded by people, I was not at ease because of those monks at Kosambī who were quarreling, arguing, and creating legal issues in the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd10:4.6.6: But now that I’m alone, without a companion, I’m happy and at ease because I’m apart from those monks at Kosambī.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.6.7: At that time there was a large bull elephant who was surrounded by a crowd of male and female elephants, by young elephants and baby elephants. He ate grass with broken tips, and other elephants ate the branches that he had folded together. He drank muddied water, and when he was immersed in a pool, the female elephants came rubbing their bodies against his.
pli-tv-kd10:4.6.10: “Let me leave the herd and stay by myself.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.7.1: He then left the herd and went to Pālileyyaka, to the Buddha at the foot of the auspicious sal tree, in the protected forest grove. And he attended on the Buddha, using his trunk to set out water for drinking and water for washing and to clear the vegetation.
pli-tv-kd10:4.7.3: “When I was previously surrounded by elephants, I was not at ease because of the other elephants.
pli-tv-kd10:4.7.4: But now that I’m alone, without a companion, I’m happy and at ease because I’m apart from those elephants.”
pli-tv-kd10:4.7.5: After considering his own seclusion and reading the mind of the elephant, the Buddha exclaimed this inspired utterance:
pli-tv-kd10:4.7.8: Agrees with the mind of the sage,
pli-tv-kd10:4.7.9: Since they each delight in the forest solitude.”
pli-tv-kd10:5.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Pālileyyaka for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd10:5.1.3: he stayed in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-kd10:5.1.4: Soon the lay followers in Kosambī considered,
pli-tv-kd10:5.1.5: “These venerable monks at Kosambī have caused us much misfortune.
pli-tv-kd10:5.1.6: The Buddha himself left because he was troubled by them.
pli-tv-kd10:5.1.7: Well then, let’s not bow down, rise up, raise our joined palms, or do acts of respect for them. And let’s not honor, respect, esteem, or associate with them, nor give them almsfood.
pli-tv-kd10:5.1.8: Because of this, they will either leave, disrobe, or reconcile with the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd10:5.2.1: And that is what they did.
pli-tv-kd10:5.2.2: Soon the monks at Kosambī said,
pli-tv-kd10:5.2.3: “Well then, let’s go to Sāvatthī and resolve this legal issue in the presence of the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd10:5.2.4.0: The account of the eighteen bases
pli-tv-kd10:5.2.4.1: The monks at Kosambī put their dwellings in order, took their bowls and robes, and went to Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd10:5.3.3: he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd10:5.3.8: “And how do I know what accords with and what is contrary to the Teaching?”
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.1: “There are eighteen bases for knowing that someone is speaking contrary to the Teaching:
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.2: A monk proclaims what contrary to the Teaching as the Teaching,
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.3: and what is the Teaching as contrary to the Teaching.
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.4: He proclaims what is contrary to the Monastic Law as the Monastic Law,
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.5: and what is the Monastic Law as contrary to the Monastic Law.
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.6: He proclaims what hasn’t been spoken by the Buddha as spoken by the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.7: and what has been spoken by the Buddha as not spoken by the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.8: He proclaims what was not practiced by the Buddha as practiced by the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.9: and what was practiced by the Buddha as not practiced by the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.10: He proclaims what was not laid down by the Buddha as laid down by the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.11: and what was laid down by the Buddha as not laid down by the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.12: He proclaims a non-offense as an offense,
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.13: and an offense as a non-offense.
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.14: He proclaims a light offense as heavy,
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.15: and a heavy offense as light.
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.16: He proclaims a curable offense as incurable,
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.17: and an incurable offense as curable.
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.18: He proclaims a grave offense as minor,
pli-tv-kd10:5.4.19: and a minor offense as grave.

pli-tv-kd10:5.10.1: Eventually those monks from Kosambī arrived at Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd10:5.10.2: Venerable Sāriputta went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd10:5.10.5: adding, “How should we prepare dwellings for these monks?”
pli-tv-kd10:5.10.6: “Give them dwellings in a separate place.”
pli-tv-kd10:5.10.7: “But what should we do if there are no dwellings in a separate place?”
pli-tv-kd10:5.10.8: “Separate the dwellings and then give them out.
pli-tv-kd10:5.10.9: Under no circumstances, Sāriputta, should a dwelling be reserved for a more senior monk.
pli-tv-kd10:5.10.10: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd10:5.10.11: “And what should we do in regard to food and requisites?”
pli-tv-kd10:5.10.12: “Food and requisites should be shared out equally to everyone.”

pli-tv-kd10:5.13.0: Discussion of unity in the Sangha
pli-tv-kd10:5.13.1: Soon afterwards the monks who were siding with the ejected monk re-admitted him. They then approached the monks who had ejected him and said,
pli-tv-kd10:5.13.2: “Because this monk has recognized that he had committed offense, and because he has been ejected and now re-admitted, the basis for the arguments and disputes in the Sangha, for the schism, fracture, and separation in the Sangha, have been removed.
pli-tv-kd10:5.13.3: To resolve this matter, let’s create unity in the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd10:5.13.4: The monks who had done the ejecting went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd10:5.13.9: adding, “How should we proceed with this?”
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.1: “Since this is the case, you should create unity in the Sangha so as to resolve this matter.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.2: And it should be done like this.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.3: Everyone should gather in one place, including those who are sick.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.5: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.6: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.7: Because this monk has recognized that he had committed an offense, and because he has been ejected and now re-admitted, the basis for the arguments and disputes in the Sangha, for the schism, fracture, and separation in the Sangha, have been removed.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.8: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, let us create unity in the Sangha so as to resolve this matter.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.10: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.11: Because this monk has recognized that he had committed an offense, and because he has been ejected and now re-admitted, the basis for the arguments and disputes in the Sangha, for the schism, fracture, and separation in the Sangha, have been removed.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.12: The Sangha is creating unity in the Sangha so as to resolve this matter.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.13: Any monk who approves of creating unity in the Sangha so as to resolve this matter should remain silent. Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.14: The Sangha has created unity in the Sangha so as to resolve this matter.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.15: The schism in the Sangha has come to an end. The fracture in the Sangha has come to an end. The separation in the Sangha has come to an end.
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.16: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-kd10:5.14.17: The observance-day procedure, the recitation of the Monastic Code, should be done straightaway.”
pli-tv-kd10:6.1.0: Upāli’s questions about unity in the Sangha
pli-tv-kd10:6.1.1: Soon afterwards Venerable Upāli went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd10:6.1.3: “Venerable Sir, if the basis for the arguments and disputes in the Sangha, for the schism, fracture, and separation in the Sangha, haven’t been investigated by the Sangha, haven’t been resolved by the Sangha, yet the Sangha creates unity in the Sangha—is that unity in the Sangha legitimate?”
pli-tv-kd10:6.1.4: “That unity in the Sangha is illegitimate.”
pli-tv-kd10:6.1.5: “If the basis for the arguments and disputes in the Sangha, for the schism, fracture, and separation in the Sangha, have been investigated by the Sangha, have been resolved by the Sangha, and the Sangha then creates unity in the Sangha—is that unity in the Sangha legitimate?”
pli-tv-kd10:6.1.6: “That unity in the Sangha is legitimate.”
pli-tv-kd10:6.2.1: “Sir, how many kinds of unity in the Sangha are there?”
pli-tv-kd10:6.2.2: “There are two kinds of unity in the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd10:6.2.3: There is the unity in the Sangha where the wording is fulfilled, but not the purpose.
pli-tv-kd10:6.2.4: And there is the unity in the Sangha where both the wording and the purpose are fulfilled.
pli-tv-kd10:6.2.6: If the basis for the arguments and disputes in the Sangha, for the schism, fracture, and separation in the Sangha, haven’t been investigated by the Sangha, haven’t been resolved by the Sangha, yet the Sangha creates unity in the Sangha, this is called unity in the Sangha where the wording is fulfilled, but not the purpose.
pli-tv-kd10:6.2.8: If the basis for the arguments and disputes in the Sangha, for the schism, fracture, and separation in the Sangha, have been investigated by the Sangha, have been resolved by the Sangha, and the Sangha then creates unity in the Sangha, this is called unity in the Sangha where both the wording and the purpose are fulfilled.”
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.1: Upāli then got up from his seat, put his upper robe over one shoulder, raise his joined palms, and spoke in verse to the Buddha:
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.2: “In regard to the business and discussions of the Sangha,
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.3: In regard to the business that arises and the deliberations—
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.4: The person who is very beneficial, how does he handle these?
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.5: How is a monk fit to deal with these?”
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.7: Watching his behavior, well-restrained in faculties—
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.8: His enemies cannot legitimately criticize him;
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.9: There is nothing for them to correct in him.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.12: Without fear, he trembles not in a gathering;
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.13: He does not mangle the meaning, but speaks to the point.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.14: If asked a question in a gathering,
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.15: He is neither diffident nor timid.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.16: His words are timely and pertinent;
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.17: He skilfully satisfies a discerning gathering.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.20: Able to investigate, clever in discussion,
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.24: He does not abandon a position,
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.25: And answers questions without hurting anyone.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.26: He is able to take on the job of messenger,
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.27: And about the business of the Sangha, they speak to him.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.28: When speaking, when sent out by the community,
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.30: As far as the bases for committing offenses,
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.32: Both these analyses he has learnt well.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.33: He is skilled in the ways of clearing offenses.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.34: If one is sent away for one’s conduct,
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.35: But once sent away one acts rightly,
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.36: There is re-admittance for one who lives thus.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.37: This too he knows, the one skilled in analysis.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.39: Whether junior, senior, or of middle standing,
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.40: The wise practice for the benefit of the many—
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.41: Such a monk is fit to deal with these.”
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.42: The tenth chapter on those from Kosambī is finished.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.64: The chapter on those from Kosambī is finished.
pli-tv-kd10:6.3.66: The canonical text of the Long Division is finished.
